In language, an 'archaism' (from the , archaÃ¯kÃ³s, 'old-fashioned, antiquated',
ultimately , archaÃ®os, 'from the beginning, ancient') is the use of a form of
speech or writing that is no longer current. This can either be done
deliberately (to achieve a specific effect) or as part of a specific jargon (for
example in law) or formula (for example in religious contexts). Many nursery
rhymes contain archaisms. Archaic elements that occur only in certain fixed
expressions (for example 'be that as it may') are not considered to be
archaisms.
